About meResources

Statistics

In this section I will collect all my posts about statistics.

Sometimes dataviz is not sufficient to understand your data. In this case there’s only one way you can rigorously approach your problem: statistics.
This is a huge field, and it’s quite easy to get lost within it. In the following you will find some material which helped me to clarify my ideas and to face data-related problems.


Have fun!

Stippe

Post list

Introduction
  1. What is statistics: Let us clarify what we are talking about
  2. Kolmogorov axioms: The mathematical foundations of statistics
  3. Interpretations of probability: What does probability mean?
  4. Common discrete probabilities: Derivation of some useful one-dimensional discrete probabilities
  5. Common continuous probabilities: Derivation of some useful one-dimensional continuous probabilities
  6. Introduction to decision theory: Making choices under uncertainty
  7. The central limit theorem: Approximating the probability when the sample size is large
Simple models
  1. The Beta-Binomial model: Dealing with binary outcomes
  2. The Poisson model: How to describe count data
  3. The Negative Binomial model: An evolution of the Poisson model
  4. Exponential model, gaussian model and their evolutions: Handling real-valued data
  5. Multidimensional distributions: Dealing with more than two categories
  6. Mixture models: When your population is made by subpopulations
Bayesian workflow
  1. Introduction to the Bayesian workflow: How to make bayesian inference in practice
  2. Trace inspection: Finding issues in MCMC convergence
  3. Predictive checks: Verifying the predictions of your model
  4. Model comparison: How to choose between models
Regression
  1. Introduction to the linear regression: Including dependence on external variables
  2. Robust linear regression: Reducing sensitivity to large deviations
  3. Logistic regression: How to perform regression on binary data
  4. Poisson regression: Regression on count data
Advanced models
  1. Hierarchical models: How to implement hierarchies
  2. Hierarchical models and meta-analysis: How hierarchical models can be used to analyze scientific literature
  3. Introduction to survival analysis: Estimating waiting times
  4. Application of survival analysis 1: Survival analysis with continouous time
  5. Introduction to Extreme Values theory: Describing rare events
  6. Random models and mixed models: Making inference on subgroups
Causal inference
  1. Causal inference: When association implies causation
  2. Randomized controlled trials: When association implies causation
  3. Instrumental variable regression: Making causal inference without randomization
  4. Difference in difference: Causal inference from 1850
  5. Regression discontinuity : Using jumps to estimate effects
  6. Synthetic control: Building a doppleganger from the control group
Time series
  1. Introduction to time series modelling: How to model time-dependent processes
  2. The autoregressive model: How to model dependence on the past
Non-parametric models
